summary: The Communications Security Act (H.R. 1717) directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to establish a council to advise on the security, reliability, and interoperability of communications networks. The council will be composed of representatives from the communications industry (excluding "not trusted" companies), public interest groups, academic institutions, and various levels of government. The council will submit reports to the FCC every two years, which will be made public. The term "not trusted" is defined, referring to entities under foreign influence or posing a national security threat. The bill aims to enhance network security and resilience.
